column1: 爷爷和父亲立即转身回头，看到十几对鬼火一样闪烁的绿眼睛和一团团遍地翻滚的钢蓝色的影子。
column2: Granddad and Father stopped in their tracks and turned to see a dozen pairs of green eyes, like will-o'-the-wisps, and several indigo shadows tumbling on the ground.

column1: 爷爷掏出枪，对着两只绿眼一甩，一道火光飞去，那两只绿眼灭了，高粱棵子里传来垂死挣扎的狗叫。
column2: Granddad took out his pistol and fired at two of the green eyes; the howl of a dying dog accompanied the extinguishing of those eyes.

column1: 爷爷连射七枪，一群受伤的狗在高粱丛中、尸体堆里滚来滚去。
column2: Granddad fired seven shots in all, and several wounded dogs writhed in agony among the corpses.

column1: 爷爷对着狗群打完了所有的子弹，没受伤的狗逃窜出几箭远，对着爷爷和父亲发出愤怒的咆哮。
column2: While he was emptying his pistol into the pack, the uninjured dogs fled into the sorghum field, out of range, where they howled furiously at the two humans.

column1: 爷爷的自来得手枪射出的最后几粒子弹飞行了三十几步远就掉在了地上。
column2: The last couple of bullets from Granddad's pistol had travelled only thirty paces or so before thudding to the ground.

column1: 父亲看到弹头在月光中翻着筋斗飞行，缓慢得伸手就可抓住。
column2: Father watched them tumble in the moonlight, so slowly he could have reached out and caught them.

column1: 枪声也失去了焦脆的青春喉咙，颇似一个耄耋之年的老头子在咳嗽吐痰。
column2: And the once crisp crack of the pistol sounded more like the phlegmatic cough of a doddering old man.

column1: 爷爷举起枪来看了一下子，脸上露出悲痛惋惜的表情。
column2: A tortured, sympathetic expression spread across Granddad's face as he looked down at the weapon in his hand.

column1: “爹，没子弹啦？” 父亲问。
column2: 'Out of bullets, Dad?'

column1: 爷爷和父亲从县城里用小山羊肚腹运载回来的五百发子弹，在十几个小时里已经发射完毕。
column2: The five hundred bullets they'd brought back from town in the goat's belly had been used up in a matter of hours.

column1: 好像人是在一天中突然衰老一样，枪也是在一天中突然衰老。 爷爷痛感到这支枪越来越违背自己的意志，跟它告别的时候到了。
column2: The pistol had aged overnight, and Granddad came to the painful realisation that it was no longer capable of carrying out his wishes; time for them to part ways.

column1: 爷爷把胳膊平伸出去，仔细地看着月光照在枪面上反射出的黯淡的光彩，然后一松手，匣子枪沉重落地。
column2: Holding the gun out in front of him, he carefully studied the muted reflection of the moonlight on the barrel, then loosened his grip and let the gun fall heavily to the ground.

column1: 那些绿眼睛的狗又向尸体聚拢过来，起初还畏畏惧惧，绿眼睛里跳着惊惧的火花。
column2: The green-eyed dogs returned to the corpses, timidly at first.

column1: 很快，绿眼睛消失，月光照着一道道波浪般翻滚的蓝色狗毛，爷爷和父亲都听到了狗嘴的吧咂声和尸体的撕裂声。
column2: But their eyes quickly disappeared, and the moonlight was reflected off rolling waves of bluish fur; Granddad and Father could hear the sounds of dogs tearing human bodies with their fangs.

column1: “爹，咱到村里去吧。”父亲说。
column2: 'Let's go into the village, Dad,' Father said.

column1: 爷爷有点犹豫，父亲拉他一把，他就跟着父亲走了。
column2: Granddad wavered for a moment, so Father tugged on him, and they fell into step.

column1: 村里的火堆多半熄灭，断壁残垣中，暗红的余烬发散着酷热，街上热风盘旋，浊气逼人，白烟和黑烟交织成团，在烧焦的、烘萎了的树梢间翻腾。
column2: By then most of the fires in the village had gone out, leaving red-hot cinders that gave off an acrid heat amid the crumbling walls and shattered buildings. Hot winds whirled above the village roads. The murky air was stifling.

column1: 木料在炭化过程中爆豆般响着，失去支撑的房屋顶盖塌下，砸起冲天的尘烟和灰烬。
column2: Roofs of houses, their supports burned out beneath them, had collapsed in mountains of smoke, dust, and cinders.

column1: 土围子上、街道上、尸体狼藉。
column2: Bodies were strewn atop the village wall and on the roads.

column1: 我们村子的历史又翻开了新的一页。
column2: A page in the history of our village had been turned.

column1: 它原先是一片蛮荒地，荆榛苇茅丛生，狐狸野兔的乐园，后来有了几架牧人的草棚，后来逃来了杀人命犯、落魄酒徒、亡命赌棍…… 他们建造房屋，开垦荒地，拓扑出人的乐园，狐狸野兔迁徙他乡，临别时齐声发出控诉人类的鸣叫。
column2: At one time the site had been a wasteland covered with brambles, underbrush, and reeds, a paradise for foxes and wild rabbits. Then a few huts appeared, and it became a haven for escaped murderers, drunks, gamblers, who built homes, cultivated the land, and turned it into a paradise for humans, forcing out the foxes and wild rabbits, who set up howls of protest on the eve of their departure.

column1: 现在它是一片废墟了，人创造的，又被人摧毁。
column2: Now the village lay in ruins; man had created it, and man had destroyed it.

column1: 真正的现在的它是在废墟上建立起来的悲喜参半的忧乐园。
column2: It was now a sorrowful paradise, a monument to both grief and joy, built upon ruins.

column1: 当一九六○年黑暗的饥馑笼罩山东大地时，我虽然年仅四岁，也隐隐约约地感觉到，高密东北乡从来就没有不是废墟过，高密东北乡人心灵里堆积着的断砖碎瓦从来就没有清理干净过，也不可能清理干净。
column2: In 1960, when the dark cloud of famine settled over the Shandong Peninsula, even though I was only four years old I could dimly sense that Northeast Gaomi Township had never been anything but a pile of ruins, and that its people had never been able to rid their hearts of the shattered buildings, nor would they ever be able to.

column1: 那天晚上，所有的房屋都烟飞火灭之后，我家那几十间房屋还在燃烧。 我家的房子燃烧时放出一些翠绿的火苗和一股醉人的酒味，潴留多年的酒气，都在火中升腾起来。
column2: That night, after the smoke and sparks from the other houses had died out, our buildings were still burning, sending skyward green-tinged tongues of flame and the intoxicating aroma of strong wine, released in an instant after all those years.

column1: 蓝色的房瓦在大火中弯曲变形，呈现暗红色，疾速地、像弹片一样从火中飞出来。 火光照着爷爷花白的头发，爷爷的满头黑发，在短短的七天里，白了四分之三。
column2: Blue roof tiles, deformed by the intense heat, turned scarlet, then leaped into the air through a wall of flames that illuminated Granddad's hair, which had turned three-quarters grey in the space of a week.

column1: 我家的房盖轰隆隆塌陷下去，火焰萎缩片刻，又疯蹿得更高。
column2: A roof came crashing down, momentarily blotting out the flames, which then roared out of the rubble, stronger than ever.

column1: 父亲和爷爷都被这一声巨响震荡得胸闷气噎。
column2: The loud crash nearly crushed the breath out of Father and Granddad.

column1: 这几十间先庇护了单家父子发财致富后庇护了爷爷放火杀人又庇护着奶奶爷爷父亲罗汉大爷与众伙计们多少恩恩怨怨的房屋完成了它的所谓的“历史的使命”。
column2: Our house, which had sheltered the father and son of the Shan family as they grew rich, then had sheltered Granddad after his murderous deed, then had sheltered Grandma, Granddad, Father, Uncle Arhat, and all the men who worked for them, a sanctuary for their kindnesses and their grievances, had now completed its historical mission.

column1: 我恨透了这个庇护所，因为它在庇护着善良、麻醉着真挚的情感的同时，也庇护着丑陋和罪恶。
column2: I hated that sanctuary: though it had sheltered decent emotions, it had also sheltered heinous crimes.

column1: 父亲，一九五七年，你躲在我家里间屋里那个地洞里时，你每日每夜，在永恒的黑暗中，追忆流水年月，你至少三百六十次想到了我们家那几十间房屋的屋盖在大火中塌落的情景。 你想到你的父亲我的爷爷在那时刻想到了什么，我的幻想紧追着你的幻想，你的幻想紧追着爷爷的思维。
column2: Father, when you were hiding in the burrow we dug for you in the floor of my home back in 1957, you recalled those days of your past in the unrelenting darkness. On no fewer than 365 occasions, in your mind you saw the roof of your house crash down amid the flames, and wondered what was going through the mind of your father, my granddad. So my fantasies were chasing yours while yours were chasing Granddad's.

column1: 爷爷看到这房屋的塌陷的感觉，就像当初爱上恋儿姑娘后，愤然抛弃我奶奶另村去住，但后来又听说奶奶在家放浪形骸与“铁板会”头子“黑眼”姘上一样，说不清是恨还是爱，说不清是痛苦还是愤怒。
column2: As he watched the roof collapse, Granddad became as angry as he'd been the day he abandoned Grandma and moved to another village to be with his new love, Passion. He had learned then that Grandma had shamelessly taken up with Black Eye, the leader of an organisation called the Iron Society, and at the time he wasn't sure what filled his heart – loathing or love, pain or anger.

column1: 爷爷后来重返奶奶的怀抱，对奶奶的感情已经混浊得难辨颜色和味道。
column2: When he later returned to Grandma's arms, his feelings for her were so confused he couldn't sort them out.

column1: 我们感情上的游击战首先把自己的心脏打得千疮百孔最后又把对方打得千疮百孔。
column2: In the beginning, his emotional warfare scarred only his own heart, and Grandma's scarred only her own. Finally, they hurt each other.

column1: 只有当奶奶在高粱地里用死亡的面容对着爷爷微笑时，他才领会到生活对自己的惩罚是多么严酷。
column2: Only when Grandma smiled up at him as she lay dead in the sorghum field did he realise the grievous punishment life had meted out to him.

column1: 他像喜鹊珍爱覆巢中最后一个卵一样珍爱着我父亲，但是，已经晚一点了，命运为他安排的更残酷的结局，已在前面路口上，胸有成竹地对他冷笑着。
column2: He loved my father as a magpie loves the last remaining egg in its nest. But by then it was too late, for fate, cold and calculating, had sentenced him to a cruel end that was waiting for him down the road.

column1: “爹，咱的家没了……” 父亲说。
column2: 'Dad, our house is gone. . . .' Father said.

column1: 爷爷摸着父亲的头，看着残破的家园，牵着父亲的手，在火光渐弱月光渐强的街道上无目标地蹒跚着。
column2: Granddad rubbed Father's head as he stared at the ruins of his home, then took Father's hand and began stumbling aimlessly down the road under the waning light of the flames and the waxing light of the moon.

column1: 村头上，一个苍老淳朴的声音问：“是小三吗？
column2: At the head of the village they heard an old man's voice: 'Is that you, Number Three?

column1: 怎么没把牛车赶来？”
column2: Why didn't you bring the oxcart?'

column1: 爷爷和父亲听到人声，倍觉亲切，忘了疲乏，急匆匆赶过去。
column2: The sound of that voice gave Granddad and Father such a warm feeling they forgot how tired they were and rushed over to see who it was.

column1: 一个弓着腰的老头，迎着他们上来，把眼睛几乎贴到爷爷脸上打量着。
column2: A hunched-over elderly man rose to greet them, carefully sizing up Granddad with his ancient eyes, nearly touching his face.

column1: 爷爷对老头那两只警觉的眼睛不满意，老头嘴里喷出的铜臭气使爷爷反感。
column2: Granddad didn't like his watchful look and was repulsed by the greedy stench that came from his mouth.

column1: “不是我家小三子。” 老头子遗憾地晃晃脑袋，坐回去。
column2: 'You're not my Number Three,' the old man said unhappily, his head wobbling as he sat down on a pile of loot.

column1: 他的屁股下边堆了一大堆杂物，有箱、柜、饭桌、农具、牲口套具、破棉絮、铁锅、瓦盆……
column2: There were trunks, cupboards, dining tables, farm tools, harnesses, ripped comforters, cooking pots, earthenware bowls.

column1: 老头坐在小山一样的货物上，像一只狼守护着自己的猎物。
column2: He was sitting on a small mountain of stuff and guarding it as a wolf guards its kill.

column1: 老头身后的柳树上，拴着两头牛犊子、三只山羊，一头小毛驴。
column2: Behind him, two calves, three goats, and a mule were tied to a willow tree.

column1: 爷爷咬牙切齿地骂道：“老狗！
column2: 'You old dog!' Granddad growled through clenched teeth.

column1: 你给我滚下来！”
column2: 'Get the hell out of here!'

column1: 老头子从货堆上蹲起，友善地说：“哎，兄弟，别眼红吆，俺这是不惧生死从火堆里抢出来的！”
column2: The old man rose up on his haunches and said amiably, 'Ah, my brother, let's not be envious. I risked my life to drag this stuff out of the flames!'

column1: “你给我下来，我操死你活妈！”
column2: 'I'll fuck your living mother! Climb down from there!'

column1: 爷爷怒骂。
column2: Granddad lashed out angrily.

column1: “你这人好没道理，我一没招你，二没惹你，你凭什么骂人？” 老头宽容地谴责着我爷爷。
column2: 'You have no right to talk to me like that. I didn't do anything to you. You're the one who's asking for trouble. What gives you the right to curse me like that?' he complained.

column1: “骂你？
column2: 'Curse you?

column1: 老子要宰了你！
column2: I'll goddamn kill you!

column1: 老子们抗日救国，与日本人拼死拼活，你们竟然趁火打劫！
column2: We're not in a desperate struggle with Japan just so you can go on a looting binge!

column1: 畜牲，老畜牲！
column2: You bastard, you old bastard!

column1: 豆官，你的枪呢？”
column2: Douguan, where's your gun?'

column1: “扔到洋马肚子底下啦！”父亲说。
column2: 'It's under the horse's belly,' Father said.

column1: 爷爷纵身跳上货堆，飞起一脚，把那老头踢到货堆下。
column2: Granddad jumped up onto the mountain of stuff and, with a single kick, sent the old man sprawling onto the ground.

column1: 老头子跪在地上，哀求道：“八路老爷饶命，八路老爷饶命……”
column2: He rose to his knees and begged, 'Spare me, Eighth Route Master, spare me!'

column1: 爷爷说：“老子不是八路，也不是九路。
column2: 'I'm not with the Eighth Route Army,' Granddad said, 'or the Ninth Route.

column1: 老子是土匪余占鳌！”
column2: I'm Yu Zhan'ao the bandit!'

column1: “余司令饶命，余司令，这些东西，放到火里也白白烧毁了……
column2: 'Spare me, Commander Yu, spare me! What good would it do to let all this stuff burn?

column1: 俺村来‘倒地瓜’的不光我一个，值钱的东西都被那些贼给抢光啦，俺老汉腿脚慢，拾掇了一点破烂……”
column2: I'm not the only "potato picker" from the village. Those thieves got all the good stuff. I'm too old and too slow, and all I could find was this junk.'

column1: 爷爷搬起一张木桌子，对准老头那秃脑门砸下去。
column2: Granddad picked up a wooden table and threw it at the old man's bald head.

column1: 老头惨叫一声，抱住流血的头，在地上转着圈乱钻。
column2: He screamed and held his bleeding scalp as he rolled in the dirt.

column1: 爷爷抓着他的衣领，把他提起来，对着那张痛苦的老脸，说：“‘倒地瓜’的好汉子！” 然后猛力捣了一拳，老头脸上腻腻地响了一声，仰面朝天摔在地上，爷爷又走上前去，对着老头的脸，狠命踹了一脚。
column2: Granddad reached down and picked him up by his collar. Looking straight into those tortured eyes, he said, 'Our hero, the "potato picker", then raised his fist and drove it with a loud crack into the old man's face, sending him crumpling to the ground, face up. Granddad walked up and kicked him in the face, hard.
